author: kishanhathiwalaCS
body:
<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

This repository is **ONLY** for PowerShell Core 6 and PowerShell 7+ issues.

- Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6).

-->
After installing v7.0.3 or v7.1.0 or even v7.2.0-preview.1, my powershell (including powershell 5.x) takes very long time to display prompt for entering commands. Powershell 5.x comes back to normal after I uninstall powershell v7.x and restart the system.

comments.author: kishanhathiwalaCS
comments.body:
The same thing happens after I open terminal in Visual Studio,
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60079091/100292365-617baf00-2fd4-11eb-96fb-f8ef5ad2c81f.png)

My powershell 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60079091/100292424-8839e580-2fd4-11eb-86b4-f526f17d0e41.png)

comments.author: kishanhathiwalaCS
comments.body:
Waiting 

> Try run pwsh -NoProfile

I did run that but the result was same. 

Although it's not happening any more. I am not sure why?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: We need repro steps to investigate an issue.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body: Anecdotally I can confirm that the startup of the very first session - only - after an installation takes much longer (haven't paid attention to how that interacts with Windows PowerShell).

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
> Anecdotally I can confirm that the startup of the very first session - only - after an installation takes much longer (haven't paid attention to how that interacts with Windows PowerShell).

If you say about Windows I guess pwsh creates explorer menu items at first run time. It could be moved to install time...
Although this should not affect Windows PowerShell.

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body: Is the code for all those .NET assemblies which PWSH loads on startup in IL, or have they been precompiled somehow into native code. There appears to be no GAC as such for the .NET 5 assemblies.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @doctordns We benefit from ReadyToRun (R2R) - all assemblies is crossgened.

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body:
> Anecdotally I can confirm that the startup of the very first session - only - after an installation takes much longer (haven't paid attention to how that interacts with Windows PowerShell).

This is Expected behaviour due to the building of the ModuleAnalysisCache which powers Get-Command/Get-Help/Get-Module which is always slow on the first run post install & has been the same since PowerShell 5.1 when they rejigged the ModuleAnalysisCache as part of the 5.1 release

comments.author: Silex
comments.body:
I have the same issue, and it's happening all the time.

Running `pwsh -NoProfile` does not change anything. It takes around 8-10 seconds for the prompt to come.

When using `-Command` the result is display instantly.

Here's what happen with normal use:

```
PS C:\Users\foo> pwsh
PowerShell 7.1.0
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation.

https://aka.ms/powershell
Type 'help' to get help.

PS C:\Users\foo> 2+2       # Previous text was displayed instantly, prompt took ~10 seconds to come
4
```

This PC is inside an organisation that has heavy policies and network restrictions, so it's probably because of this.

How can I debug this further? IMHO it's clearly PSReadline that takes a while to arrive.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @Silex If you think it is PSRL you can run without it by `pwsh -NoInteractive`.

comments.author: Silex
comments.body:
@iSazonov: yes, using `pwsh -NonInteractive` works instantly.

What should I do to debug this further?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
@Silex Please open new issue in [PSReadline ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PSReadLine) repository and @daxian-dbw would work with you.
I'd suggest you to use Wireshark to collect network traffic and investigate DNS issues.

title: It takes very long time to display prompt for entering commands
